title: Guide: Staged Patient Matching and Time-based Episode Grouping with EpiDM
text: epidm R package provides utilities support patient identity resolution clinical episode construction. vignette introduces two key functions: uk_patient_id() Identifying patients generating unique patient ids using known patient identifiers multiple staged rules. group_time() Groups time intervals clinically meaningful episodes (static rolling windows). functions designed healthcare data, example SGSS, HES/SUS data ECDS data repeated records across systems must linked aggregated.

title: Guide: Staged Patient Matching and Time-based Episode Grouping with EpiDM
text: dataset ideally contain: NHS number Hospital number Date birth Sex Forename Surname Postcode must also supply list mapping column names using id = list(...) argument.

title: Guide: Staged Patient Matching and Time-based Episode Grouping with EpiDM

title: Guide: Staged Patient Matching and Time-based Episode Grouping with EpiDM
text: dataset ideally contain: One grouping variables (e.g., patient ID, organism, specimen type) start date column (date_start) intervals: end date column (date_end) events: window (integer, days) window_type (“static” “rolling”) must also supply grouping date arguments via function parameters: group_vars (character vector column names) date_start Plus either date_end (intervals) window + window_type (events) Optional: indx_varname, min_varname, max_varname control output column names

title: Guide: Staged Patient Matching and Time-based Episode Grouping with EpiDM
text: group_time() aggregates: Intervals (start + end dates) e.g., hospital spells (HES/SUS) Events (single date) e.g., microbiology specimen dates Two episode rules supported:

title: Guide: Staged Patient Matching and Time-based Episode Grouping with EpiDM
code: # Events example (14‑day static window): #1) Create example data  episode_test <- structure(   list(     pat_id = c(1L, 1L, 1L, 1L, 2L, 2L, 2L, 1L, 1L, 1L, 1L, 2L, 2L, 2L),     species = c(rep("E. coli", 7), rep("K. pneumonia", 7)),     spec_type = c(rep("Blood", 7), rep("Blood", 4), rep("Sputum", 3)),     sp_date = structure(       c(         18262,         18263,         18281,         18282,         18262,         18263,         18281,         18265,         18270,         18281,         18283,         18259,         18260,         18281       ),       class = "Date"     )   ),   row.names = c(NA, -14L),   class = "data.frame" )  # 2) Run group_time() for events using a 14-day static window ep_static <- group_time(   x = episode_test,   date_start = 'sp_date',   window = 14,   window_type = 'static',   group_vars = c('pat_id', 'species', 'spec_type'),   indx_varname = 'static_indx',   # optional   min_varname = 'min_date',   # optional (defaults)   max_varname = 'max_date'      # optional (defaults) ) # 3) Show a preview print(head(ep_static), row.names = FALSE) #>  pat_id      species spec_type    sp_date static_indx   min_date   max_date #>   <int>       <char>    <char>     <Date>      <char>     <Date>     <Date> #>       1      E. coli     Blood 2020-01-01       1.4.1 2020-01-01 2020-01-02 #>       1      E. coli     Blood 2020-01-02       1.4.1 2020-01-01 2020-01-02 #>       1      E. coli     Blood 2020-01-20       1.4.2 2020-01-20 2020-01-21 #>       1      E. coli     Blood 2020-01-21       1.4.2 2020-01-20 2020-01-21 #>       1 K. pneumonia     Blood 2020-01-04       2.4.1 2020-01-04 2020-01-09 #>       1 K. pneumonia     Blood 2020-01-09       2.4.1 2020-01-04 2020-01-09   # Intervals example (start + end dates):1) Create example interval data (start + end dates) #1) Create example data spell_test <- data.frame(   id = c(rep(99, 6), rep(88, 4), rep(3, 3)),   provider = c("YXZ", rep("ZXY", 5), rep("XYZ", 4), rep("YZX", 3)),   spell_start = as.Date(     c(       "2020-03-01",       "2020-07-07",       "2020-02-08",       "2020-04-28",       "2020-03-15",       "2020-07-01",       "2020-01-01",       "2020-01-12",       "2019-12-25",       "2020-03-28",       "2020-01-01",       NA,       NA     )   ),   spell_end = as.Date(     c(       "2020-03-10",       "2020-07-26",       "2020-05-22",       "2020-04-30",       "2020-05-20",       "2020-07-08",       "2020-01-23",       "2020-03-30",       "2020-01-02",       "2020-04-20",       "2020-01-01",       NA,       NA     )   ) )  # 2) Run group_time() for intervals (start + end dates) spell_episodes <- group_time(   x = spell_test,   date_start = 'spell_start',   date_end = 'spell_end',   group_vars = c('id', 'provider'),   indx_varname = 'spell_id',   # optional   min_varname = 'spell_min_date',   # optional   max_varname = 'spell_max_date'        # optional )  # 3) Show a preview print(head(spell_episodes), row.names = FALSE) #>     id provider spell_start  spell_end spell_id spell_min_date spell_max_date #>  <num>   <char>      <Date>     <Date>   <char>         <Date>         <Date> #>     88      XYZ  2019-12-25 2020-01-02    1.4.0     2019-12-25     2020-04-20 #>     88      XYZ  2020-01-01 2020-01-23    1.4.0     2019-12-25     2020-04-20 #>      3      YZX  2020-01-01 2020-01-01    2.1.0     2020-01-01     2020-01-01 #>     88      XYZ  2020-01-12 2020-03-30    1.4.0     2019-12-25     2020-04-20 #>     99      ZXY  2020-02-08 2020-05-22    3.5.0     2020-02-08     2020-05-22 #>     99      YXZ  2020-03-01 2020-03-10    4.1.0     2020-03-01     2020-03-10

what: Using uk_patient_id() and group_time() together with SGSS and CIMS data
title: Guide: Staged Patient Matching and Time-based Episode Grouping with EpiDM
code: # Example data generation  # Helper to make plausible 10-digit NHS-like strings mk_nhs <- function(n) {   apply(matrix(sample(0:9, n * 10, replace = TRUE), nrow = n, byrow = TRUE),         1, paste0, collapse = "") }  # A small "people" frame to borrow shared attributes from persons <- tibble::tibble(   id_person     = 1:6,   nhsnumber     = c(mk_nhs(5), NA_character_),   # include one missing NHS   forename      = c("John", "Jane", "Sam", "Aisha", "Maya", "John"),   surname       = c("Smith", "Doe", "Patel", "Khan", "Brown", "Smyth"),  # one spelling variant   date_of_birth = as.Date(c("1980-03-14","1991-11-02","1985-07-28","2002-01-09","2010-05-30","1980-03-14")),   sex           = c("M","F","M","F","U","M"),   postcode      = c("SW1A 1AA","E1 6AN","B1 1AA","M1 1AE","CF10 1EP","SW1A1AA") # one without space )  # --- SGSS-like data: multiple specimens per person, some within 30 days ------ sgss_data <- persons |>    # duplicate person 1 (two specimens), and include others   slice(c(1, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6)) |>    mutate(     CDR_OPIE_ID            = row_number() + 1000L,     earliest_specimen_date = as.Date("2023-10-01") + c(0, 10, 5, 15, 40, 3, 2),     GROUP_A_STREP_PCR      = c("Detected","Not detected","Detected","Detected","Not detected","Detected","Detected"),     third                  = c("emm1","emm1","emm3","emm12","",NA,"emm89")   ) |>    select(     CDR_OPIE_ID, nhsnumber, forename, surname, date_of_birth, sex,     postcode, earliest_specimen_date, GROUP_A_STREP_PCR, third   )  # --- CIMS-like data: case notifications, some within 30 days of SGSS ---------- cims_data <- persons |>    # person 3 appears twice, person 1 appears once etc.   slice(c(1, 2, 3, 3, 4, 6)) %>%   mutate(     Case_identifier = row_number() + 2000L,     Date_entered    = as.Date("2023-10-05") + c(0,  6,  18,  50,  35,  1),     Infection       = c("iGAS","Scarlet fever","iGAS","iGAS","Scarlet fever","iGAS")   ) |>    select(     Case_identifier, nhsnumber, forename, surname, date_of_birth,     sex, postcode, Date_entered, Infection   )  # Example start:  # Example of importing SGSS and CIMS data ready for linkage lnk.data_sgss <- sgss_data lnk.data_cims <- cims_data  # Update SGSS column classes so they match with CIMS lnk.data_sgss <- lnk.data_sgss |>   mutate(     date_of_birth = as.Date(date_of_birth),     forename = as.character(forename),     surname = as.character(surname),     postcode = as.character(postcode),     patient_demog_sex = as.character(sex),     earliest_specimen_date = as.Date(earliest_specimen_date),     nhsnumber =  as.character(nhsnumber)   )   # Update CIMS column classes so they match SGSS lnk.data_cims <- lnk.data_cims |>   mutate(     date_of_birth = as.Date(date_of_birth),     forename = as.character(forename),     surname = as.character(surname),     postcode = as.character(postcode),     sex = as.character(sex),     Date_entered = as.Date(Date_entered))  # Convert data.frame to data.table so can be fed into function lnk.dt_cims <- data.table::setDT(lnk.data_cims) lnk.dt_sgss <- data.table::setDT(lnk.data_sgss)  # Stack the two data sets lnk.dt_combined <-   bind_rows(     mutate(lnk.dt_cims, data_source = "dt_cims"),     mutate(lnk.dt_sgss, data_source = "dt_sgss")   )  # Add common date field to be used during deduplication lnk.dt_combined <- lnk.dt_combined |>   mutate(common_date = (coalesce(earliest_specimen_date, Date_entered)))   # List of id fields to be used during normalisation of id fields # This is a parameter that is fed into the uk_patient_id() function id = list(   nhs_number = 'nhsnumber',   date_of_birth = 'date_of_birth',   sex_mfu = 'sex',   forename = 'forename',   surname = 'surname',   postcode = 'postcode' )  # Feeding combined SGSS and CIMS data into uk_patient_id() function to get  # unique patient identifiers lnk.dt_combined_norm <- epidm::uk_patient_id(   lnk.dt_combined,   id,   .useStages = c(1:6),   .sortOrder = 'common_date',   .forceCopy = TRUE,   .keepValidNHS = FALSE,    .keepStages = TRUE ) #> Warning in .f(.x[[i]], ...): NHS number is missing or empty #> Warning in .f(.x[[i]], ...): NHS number is missing or empty  # Group records by `id` into rolling 30-day windows based on `common_date`, # using `dedupe_key` as the unique row index; the trailing [] forces evaluation and returns a data.table lnk.dt_combined_grouped <- epidm::group_time(   x = lnk.dt_combined_norm,   date_start = 'common_date',   window = 30,   window_type = 'rolling',   indx_varname = 'dedup_key',   group_vars = c(     "id"   ) )[]  # Filter to pull out just CIMS data lnk.grouped_cims <- lnk.dt_combined_grouped |>   filter(data_source == "dt_cims") |>   select (     id,     Case_identifier,     date_of_birth,     forename,     surname,     nhsnumber,     postcode,     Infection,     sex,     common_date,     data_source,     dedup_key   )  # Filter to pull out just SGSS data lnk.grouped_sgss <- lnk.dt_combined_grouped |>   filter(data_source == "dt_sgss") |>   select (     CDR_OPIE_ID,     id,     date_of_birth,     forename,     surname,     nhsnumber,     postcode,     GROUP_A_STREP_PCR,     common_date,     data_source,     dedup_key,     third   )  # Taking one row from each split - gives one episode per dataset lnk.grouped_cims_deduped <- lnk.grouped_cims |>    group_by(dedup_key) |>    slice(1) |>    ungroup()   # De-duplicating SGSS- prioritising earliest emm typing with a relevant result lnk.grouped_sgss_deduped <- lnk.grouped_sgss |>    group_by(dedup_key) |>    arrange(dedup_key, common_date) |>      slice(1) |>     ungroup()   # Join splits by dedup key- common field names with .x refer to CIMS and .y for SGSS lnk.split_join_cims_sgss <-   full_join(lnk.grouped_cims_deduped, lnk.grouped_sgss_deduped, by = "dedup_key")

title: Continuous Inpatient (CIP) Spells — cip_spells
text: Creates Continuous Inpatient (CIP) spells combining one provider spells single uninterrupted period inpatient care. CIP definitions follow NHS Digital methodology: transfers providers can part CIP spell specific admission, discharge, timing criteria met. CIP spell begins patient admitted consultant care ends discharged die. http://content.digital.nhs.uk/media/11859/Provider-Spells-Methodology/pdf/Spells_Methodology.pdf spells meet CIP criteria, merged continuous spell. output includes CIP index derived start end dates full CIP period.

title: Continuous Inpatient (CIP) Spells — cip_spells

title: Continuous Inpatient (CIP) Spells — cip_spells
text: x data.frame data.table; converted data.table (usually HES/SUS data) group_vars Character vector variables used group records (minimum: patient identifier). spell_start_date Quoted column name containing provider spell admission date. admission_method CDS admission method code. admission_source CDS admission source code. spell_end_date Quoted column name containing provider spell discharge date. discharge_destination CDS discharge destination code. patient_classification CDS patient classification code. .forceCopy Logical (default FALSE). FALSE, input converted data.table modified reference. TRUE, input must already data.table, function create explicit copy avoid modifying original object.

what: Grouping of intervals or events that occur close together in time — group_time
title: Grouping of intervals or events that occur close together in time — group_time
text: utility function group together observations represent overlapping date intervals (e.g., hospital admission spells) events occurring within defined time window e.g., specimen dates grouped infection episodes. function supports : • Interval-based grouping: records start end date; overlapping intervals grouped together. • Event-based grouping: records start date grouped using either static rolling time window. output provides unique index per group minimum/maximum date define resulting aggregated episode interval.

title: Grouping of intervals or events that occur close together in time — group_time
code: group_time(   x,   date_start,   date_end,   window,   window_type = c("rolling", "static"),   group_vars,   indx_varname = "indx",   min_varname = "date_min",   max_varname = "date_max",   .forceCopy = FALSE )

title: Grouping of intervals or events that occur close together in time — group_time
text: x data.frame data.table containing date variables grouping. converted data.table internally. date_start Quoted column name giving start date record. date_end column containing end dates interval, quoted window integer representing time window days applied start date grouping events window_type character, determine 'rolling' 'static' grouping method used grouping events. 'static' window identify first event, records X days event attributed episode. Eg. 14 day window, first event 01 Mar, events day 7 Mar 14 Mar grouped, event starting 15 Mar days start new episode. 'rolling' window resets day counter new event. Eg. Events 01 Mar, 07 Mar, 14 Mar 15 Mar included single episode, additional events 29 Mar (assuming 14-day window). group_vars Character vector quoted column names used partition data grouping. indx_varname character string set variable name index column provides grouping key; default indx min_varname character string set variable name time period minimum max_varname character string set variable name time period maximum .forceCopy default FALSE; TRUE force data.table take copy instead editing data without reference indx; renamed using indx_varname id field new aggregated events/intervals; note date_start NA, indx value also NA min_date; renamed using min_varname start date aggregated events/intervals max_date; renamed using max_varname end date aggregated events/intervals

title: Grouping of intervals or events that occur close together in time — group_time
text: data.table containing original columns plus:

title: Grouping of intervals or events that occur close together in time — group_time

title: Grouping of intervals or events that occur close together in time — group_time
text: date_start date_end provided, function identifies overlapping intervals within group_vars grouping. intervals overlap combined single episode. method typically used : Hospital spells (HES/SUS) Contact periods inpatient stays

title: Grouping of intervals or events that occur close together in time — group_time
text: date_start supplied, records grouped using time window defined window argument. Two approaches supported: window_type = "static" fixed window applied starting first event group. events occurring within window grouped gap exceeds threshold, point new episode begins. window_type = "rolling" dynamic window event extends episode end point. event grouped long occurs within window days recent event episode.

title: Grouping of intervals or events that occur close together in time — group_time
text: Records missing date_start grouped returned indx = NA. rows appended back final output.

title: Grouping of intervals or events that occur close together in time — group_time
text: group_time() might used pipeline 1) SGSS specimen data – infection episode grouping (event-based) organism/specimen harmonisation (e.g., via lookup_recode()), group_time() groups specimen dates infection episodes using defined time window. helps identify clusters related positive tests patient organism. 2) HES/SUS inpatient data – continuous spell grouping (interval-based) start end dates inpatient stays available, group_time() collapses overlapping intervals single continuous hospital spell. used linking SGSS infection episodes inpatient activity. 3) Integration across datasets outputs group_time() used downstream determine whether infection events fall within around periods hospital care, enabling combined SGSS–HES/SUS–ECDS analyses.

Hospital IN/OUT dates — hospital_in_out_dates
text: Derives per‑patient hospital entry (hospital_in) exit (hospital_out) dates reconciling &E (ECDS) attendances inpatient (HES/SUS) spells. Applies simple ranking determine relevant hospital period around index event date (e.g., specimen collection date). "1" Current admissions take priority "2" conflicting day, inpatient admissions take priority &E emergency care data "3" patient linked &E admission hospital inpatient stay, &E admission date used "4" patient positive test two hospital stays recent completed hospital stay prior test retained except time events greater 14 days, first admission following test retained

what: Link A&E (ECDS) records to Inpatient (HES/SUS) spells — link_ae_inpatient
title: Link A&E (ECDS) records to Inpatient (HES/SUS) spells — link_ae_inpatient
text: Links Emergency Care Data Set (ECDS) &E records inpatient spells (HES/SUS) using patient identifiers (NHS number, hospital number, date birth), organisation code, link date. inpatient records already aggregated desired spell level (e.g., provider spell, CIP, “mega” spell). output patient-level linked table suitable downstream pathway analysis.

title: Link A&E (ECDS) records to Inpatient (HES/SUS) spells — link_ae_inpatient
code: link_ae_inpatient(   ae = list(data, record_id = "unique_record_id", nhs_number = "nhs_number",     hospital_number = "local_patient_identifier", patient_dob = "patient_birth_date",     org_code = "organisation_code_of_provider", arrival_date = "arrival_date",     departure_date = "departure_date"),   inp = list(data, record_id = "unique_record_id", nhs_number = "nhs_number",     hospital_number = "local_patient_identifier", patient_dob = "date_birth", org_code =     "organisation_code_code_of_provider", spell_id = "mega_spell_id", spell_start_date =     "spell_start_date"),   .forceCopy = FALSE )

title: Link A&E (ECDS) records to Inpatient (HES/SUS) spells — link_ae_inpatient
text: ae named list describing &E (ECDS) input quoted column names: data ECDS &E dataset (unquoted object). record_id Optional unique row id retain. arrival_date &E arrival date column. departure_date &E departure date column. nhs_number NHS number column. hospital_number Local patient identifier column. patient_dob Date birth column. org_code Provider organisation code column. inp named list describing inpatient (HES/SUS) input quoted column names: data Inpatient dataset (unquoted object). record_id Optional unique row id retain. spell_start_date Inpatient spell start/admission date column. spell_id Spell identifier carry (e.g., CIP mega spell id). nhs_number NHS number column. hospital_number Local patient identifier column. patient_dob Date birth column. org_code Provider organisation code column. .forceCopy Logical (default FALSE). FALSE, input converted data.table modified reference. TRUE, input must already data.table, function create explicit copy avoid modifying original object.

title: Link A&E (ECDS) records to Inpatient (HES/SUS) spells — link_ae_inpatient
text: linked data.table patient/spell level containing: Harmonised identifiers (NHS number / hospital number, DOB, org code) &E arrival/departure dates Inpatient spell identifiers spell start date (supplied) preserved record_id columns (tagged *_ae / *_inp)

title: Link A&E (ECDS) records to Inpatient (HES/SUS) spells — link_ae_inpatient
text: Use link_ae_inpatient() : ECDS &E data cleaned/standardised (e.g., discharge categories via lookup_recode()). Lookup table switch handler — lookup_recode
text: function recode values via named lookup tables (.e call epidm lookup table recode aware new value). routes specific lookup based type, returning character vector input value mapped corresponding replacement. value found lookup original value returned. Built‑lookups include: species: Uses respeciate_organism dataset standardise reclassify organism names (e.g., historic → current nomenclature). supports consistent reporting across SGSS laboratory datasets. specimen: Uses specimen_type_grouping dataset assign raw laboratory specimen types harmonised specimen groups. enables consistent grouping reporting, aggregation, filtering. genus_gram_stain: Uses genus_gram_stain lookup table, provides Gram stain classifications bacterial genus. reference manually maintained UKHSA SGSS database supports rapid filtering high‑level organism categorisation. Users raise issue submit pull request epidm GitHub repository organism/genus missing. lab_data: Uses lab_data lookup dataset harmonising laboratory code systems internal SGSS mappings, supporting standardised laboratory result interpretation within surveillance pipelines. inpatient_admission_method: Uses internal lookup table epidm:::group_inpatient_admission_method categorise raw hospital admission method codes operationally meaningful groups. inpatient_discharge_destination: Uses internal table epidm:::group_inpatient_discharge_destination group hospital discharge destination codes standardised categories inpatient pathway analysis. ecds_destination_code: Uses internal table epidm:::group_ecds_discharge_destination, providing grouped mappings ECDS (Emergency Care Data Set) discharge codes. manual: Allows user supply lookup .import = list(new, old). useful working local, provisional, evolving code sets yet included package’s centralised lookup tables.

One : 'species', 'specimen', 'inpatient_admission_method', 'inpatient_discharge_destination', 'ecds_destination_code', 'manual'. .import two‑element list format list(new, old) used type = 'manual'. element must vector equal length.

title: Patient ID record grouping — uk_patient_id
text: Assigns single integer id records belong patient applying sequence deterministic matching stages across common identifiers (NHS number, hospital number, DOB, name, sex, postcode). Identifiers standardised, validated using NHS checksum function, fuzzy name keys used later stages. ' Matching performed order following stages (first match applied): NHS number + date birth Hospital number + date birth NHS number + hospital number NHS number + surname Hospital number + surname Date birth + surname (NHS invalid/absent) Sex + full name (forename + surname) Sex + date birth + fuzzy name (Soundex; surname + initial) Date birth (YYYY-MM) + fuzzy name Surname/forename + postcode Name swaps (forename/surname reversed) + date birth Use .useStages restrict stages applied (default: 1:11). function generates reproducible id per patient within sort order; can provide .sortOrder (e.g., date column) make assignment deterministic. Validity rules applied: NHS number validated using standard checksum (epidm::valid_nhs()). Hospital number: excludes known placeholders (e.g., "UNKNOWN", "PATIENT ID"). DOB: excludes proxy missing dates ("1900-01-01", "1800-01-01", NA). Sex: normalised "M" / "F"; others → NA. Names: uppercased, Latin characters normalised; Soundex used fuzzy matching. Identifiers copied missing invalid grouped records.

title: NHS Number Validity Check — valid_nhs
text: Validates NHS numbers using NHS checksum applied first 9 digits compared 10th digit. Inputs exactly 10 numeric characters invalid. Numbers made repeated digit (e.g., "1111111111", "0000000000") also rejected.

title: NHS Number Validity Check — valid_nhs
code: valid_nhs(nhs_number)

title: NHS Number Validity Check — valid_nhs
text: nhs_number vector values validate. element coerced character length checking digit extraction.

title: NHS Number Validity Check — valid_nhs
text: numeric vector length nhs_number containing: 1 value valid NHS number 0 otherwise

title: NHS Number Validity Check — valid_nhs
text: Algorithm (summary): Take first 9 digits multiply weights 10 2 (.e., d1×10 + d2×9 + … + d9×2). Compute 11 - (sum %% 11) → expected check digit. expected check digit 11, treat 0. Compare 10th digit. match, number valid. Additional guards implemented: NHS number NA 10 characters, invalid. 10 digits identical (e.g., "1111111111"), invalid. function vectorised returns 1 valid 0 invalid element input vector.
